sentences.sentence: The walls rose very high all round that courtyard.
They had many great windows in them, windows without glass, through which you saw nothing but black darkness.
Lower down there were great pillared( 柱式的 ) arches( 拱门 ), yawning( 裂开 ) blackly like the mouths of railway( 铁路 ) tunnels( 隧道 ). It was rather cold.
The stone of which everything was built seemed to be red, but that might only be because of the curious light.
It was obviously very old. Many of the flat stones that paved( 铺（地面） ) the courtyard had cracks( 裂缝 ) across them.
None of them fitted closely together and the sharp( 尖尖的 ) corners were all worn off.
One of the arched( 拱形的 ) doorways( 门口 ) was half filled up( 铺满 ) with rubble( 碎石 ).
The two children kept on turning round and round to look at the different sides of the courtyard.
One reason was that they were afraid of somebody—or something—looking out of those windows at them when their backs were turned.
“Do you think anyone lives here?” said Digory at last, still in a whisper.
“No,” said Polly. “It’s all in ruins. We haven’t heard a sound since we came.”
“Let’s stand still and listen for a bit,” suggested Digory.
They stood still and listened, but all they could hear was the thump-thump( 扑通扑通声 ) of their own hearts.
This place was at least as quiet as the Wood between the Worlds.
But it was a different kind of quietness.
The silence of the Wood had been rich and warm (you could almost hear the trees growing) and full of life: this was a dead, cold, empty silence.
You couldn’t imagine anything growing in it.
“Let’s go home,” said Polly.
“But we haven’t seen anything yet,” said Digory. “Now we’re here, we simply must have a look round.”
“I’m sure there’s nothing at all interesting here.”
“There’s not much point in finding a magic ring that lets you into other worlds if you’re afraid to look at them when you’ve got there.”
“Who’s talking about being afraid?” said Polly, letting go of Digory’s hand.
“I only thought you didn’t seem very keen( 热衷的 ) on exploring this place.”
“I’ll go anywhere you go.”
“We can get away the moment we want to,” said Digory. “Let’s take off our green rings and put them in our right-hand pockets.
All we’ve got to do is to remember that our yellow are in our left-hand pockets.
You can keep your hand as near your pocket as you like, but don’t put it in or you’ll touch your yellow and vanish( 消失 ).”
They did this and went quietly up to one of the big arched( 拱形的 ) doorways which led into the inside of the building.
And when they stood on the threshold( 门槛 ) and could look in, they saw it was not so dark inside as they had thought at first.
It led into a vast, shadowy hall which appeared to be empty;
but on the far side there was a row of pillars( 柱子 ) with arches( 拱门 ) between them and through those arches( 拱门 ) there streamed in some more of the same tired-looking light.
They crossed the hall, walking very carefully for fear of holes in the floor or of anything lying about that they might trip over.
It seemed a long walk. When they had reached the other side they came out through the arches( 拱门 ) and found themselves in another and larger courtyard.
“That doesn’t look very safe,” said Polly,
pointing at a place where the wall bulged( 凸起 ) outward( 向外 ) and looked as if it were ready to fall over into the courtyard.
In one place a pillar( 柱子 ) was missing between two arches( 拱门 ) and the bit that came down to where the top of the pillar( 柱子 ) ought to have been hung there with nothing to support it.
Clearly, the place had been deserted for hundreds, perhaps thousands, of years.
“If it’s lasted till now, I suppose it’ll last a bit longer,” said Digory. “But we must be very quiet.
You know a noise sometimes brings things down—like an avalanche( 雪崩 ) in the Alps.”
They went on out of that courtyard into another doorway,
and up a great flight of steps and through vast rooms that opened out of one another till you were dizzy( 眩晕的 ) with the mere size of the place.
Every now and then they thought they were going to get out into the open and see what sort of country lay around the enormous( 庞大的 ) palace.
But each time they only got into another courtyard.
They must have been magnificent( 宏伟的 ) places when people were still living there.
In one there had once been a fountain.
A great stone monster( 石兽 ) with wide-spread( 张开的 ) wings stood with its mouth open and you could still see a bit of piping at the back of its mouth, out of which the water used to pour.
Under it was a wide stone basin to hold the water; but it was as dry as a bone.
In other places there were the dry sticks of some sort of climbing plant( 攀缘植物 ) which had wound itself round the pillars( 柱子 ) and helped to pull some of them down( 把...毁坏掉 ).
But it had died long ago. And there were no ants or spiders( 蜘蛛 ) or any of the other living things you expect to see in a ruin;
and where the dry earth showed between the broken flagstones( 石板 )  there was no grass or moss( 青苔 ).
It was all so dreary( 沉闷的 ) and all so much the same that even Digory was thinking they had better put on their yellow rings and get back to the warm, green, living forest of the in-between place,
when they came to two huge doors of some metal that might possibly be gold.
One stood a little ajar( 微开着 ). So of course they went to look in. Both started back and drew a long breath:
for here at last was something worth seeing.
For a second they thought the room was full of people—hundreds of people, all seated, and all perfectly still.
Polly and Digory, as you may guess, stood perfectly still themselves for a good long time, looking in.
But presently they decided that what they were looking at could not be real people.
There was not a movement nor the sound of a breath among them all. They were like the most wonderful waxworks( 蜡像 )  you ever saw.
This time Polly took the lead.
There was something in this room which interested her more than it interested Digory: all the figures were wearing magnificent( 华丽的 ) clothes.
If you were interested in clothes at all, you could hardly help going in to see them closer.
And the blaze( 光辉 ) of their colors made this room look, not exactly cheerful, but at any rate rich and majestic( 壮丽的 ) after all the dust and emptiness of the others.
It had more windows, too, and was a good deal lighter.
I can hardly describe the clothes.
The figures were all robed( 身披长袍的 ) and had crowns( 皇冠 ) on their heads.
Their robes( 长袍 ) were of crimson( 深红色 ) and silvery gray and deep purple and vivid( 鲜艳的 ) green:
and there were patterns, and pictures of flowers and strange beasts, in needlework( 刺绣 ) all over them.
Precious( 珍贵的 ) stones of astonishing( 惊人的 ) size and brightness stared from their crowns( 皇冠 ) and hung in chains round their necks and peeped out from all the places where anything was fastened.
“Why haven’t these clothes all rotted away( 腐烂 ) long ago?” asked Polly.
“Magic,” whispered Digory. “Can’t you feel it? I bet( 打赌 ) this whole room is just stiff( 死气沉沉的 ) with enchantments( 魔咒 ). I could feel it the moment we came in.”
“Any one of these dresses would cost hundreds of pounds,” said Polly.
But Digory was more interested in the faces, and indeed these were well worth looking at.
The people sat in their stone chairs on each side of the room and the floor was left free down the middle.
You could walk down and look at the faces in turn.
“They were nice people, I think,” said Digory.
Polly nodded. All the faces they could see were certainly nice.
Both the men and women looked kind and wise, and they seemed to come of a handsome race.
But after the children had gone a few steps down the room they came to faces that looked a little different.
These were very solemn( 严肃的 ) faces.
You felt you would have to mind your P’s and Q’s, if you ever met living people who looked like that.
When they had gone a little further, they found themselves among faces they didn’t like: this was about the middle of the room.
The faces here looked very strong and proud and happy, but they looked cruel.
A little further on they looked crueler.
Further on again, they were still cruel but they no longer looked happy.
They were even despairing( 绝望的 ) faces: as if the people they belonged to had done dreadful( 可怕的 ) things and also suffered dreadful( 可怕的 ) things.
The last figure of all was the most interesting—a woman even more richly dressed than the others,
very tall (but every figure in that room was taller than the people of our world), with a look of such fierceness and pride that it took your breath away.
Yet she was beautiful too. Years afterward( 之后 ) when he was an old man, Digory said he had never in all his life known a woman so beautiful.
It is only fair to add that Polly always said she couldn’t see anything specially beautiful about her.
This woman, as I said, was the last: but there were plenty of( 许多 ) empty chairs beyond her,
as if the room had been intended( 打算 ) for a much larger collection of( 一堆 ) images.
“I do wish we knew the story that’s behind all this,” said Digory. “Let’s go back and look at that table sort of thing in the middle of the room.”

article_info.previous: 为了验证戒指是否能带Polly和Digory回家，他们做了一次实验，结果证明戒指是有效的。谨慎的Polly提议Digory在来时的水池边做了一个标记，两人又开始了另一番的神秘历险。那么，接下来他们会到达什么地方呢？

article_info.share_words: The figures were all robed ad had crowns on their heads. Their robes were of crimson and silvery gray and deep purple and vivid green: the there were patterns, and pictures of flowers and strange beasts, in needlework all over them.

question.cn: 站在院子里的Polly和Digory是什么感觉？
question.en: How did Polly and Digory feel when they stood in the courtyard?

analysis: 文中提到“The two children kept on turning round and round to look at the different sides of the courtyard. One reason was that they were afraid of somebody. ”此处当Digory和Polly来到这个陌生的院子时，两个孩子是十分害怕的。因此选B.

question.cn: 站在院子里的Polly和Digory听见了什么？
question.en: When Polly and Digory stood still in the courtyard,what did they hear?

analysis: 文中提到“They stood still and listened, but all they could hear was the thump-thump of their own hearts. This place was at least as quiet as the Wood between the Worlds.”因为周围太安静了，所以Polly和Digory只能听见自己的心跳声。因此选B.

question.cn: Polly和Digory感到害怕时，是谁建议他们回家？
question.en: When Polly and Digory felt afraid,who suggested that they should go home?

analysis: 文中提到“Let’s go home, said Polly.”此时两个孩子非常害怕，所以Polly就建议不如带上戒指回家。因此选C.

question.cn: Polly和Digory认为巨大的金属门后面是什么呢？
question.en: According to Polly and Digory,what was behind the huge metal doors?

analysis: 文中提到“For a second they thought the room was full of people; hundreds of people, all seated, and all perfectly still.”在Polly和Digory在没进入那扇金属门之前，以为里面坐着的满满的活人。因此选B.

question.cn: Digory觉得哪一个蜡像最有意思？
question.en: According to Digory, which figure did he think was the most interesting one?

analysis: 文中提到“The last figure of all was the most interesting-a woman even more richly dressed than the others, very tall…with a look of such fierceness and pride that it took your breath away.”在这么多的蜡像中，Digory觉得最后一位女人的形象是最有意思的。因此选C.

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第22天
